case_vignette: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless skin lesion on his neck. The lesion has gradually become darker in color. Sometimes it is itchy. He also noticed one similar lesion on his lower back. He is a retired gardener. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 123/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule on his neck and a 0.6-cm hyperpigmented papule on his lower back, both of which have a greasy and wax-like appearance. A photograph of the neck is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've had a painless spot on my neck for 3 months that's been getting darker, and it's sometimes itchy. I also found a similar spot on my lower back.
Is there any change in the size or shape of these spots?
No, I haven't noticed any change in the size or shape, just that they have become darker.
Have you noticed any changes in the texture of these spots, like becoming thicker or developing a rough surface?
Yes, they feel greasy and wax-like.
Do you have a history of heavy sun exposure or sunburns?
I worked as a gardener before I retired.
Have you had any similar spots in the past, or do you have a family history of skin conditions?
No, this is the first time, and there's no family history of skin conditions that I know of.
Have you been using any new skin products, soaps, or have you been exposed to new substances that could have come in contact with the affected areas?
No, I haven't used any new skin products or been exposed to new substances.
Are the borders of the spots well-defined, and do you see any variations in pigmentation within the spots?
I can't tell much about the borders or color variations myself.
Have you experienced any recent weight loss, loss of appetite, night sweats, or fever?
No, I haven't had any of those issues.
How old are you, and what is your sex?
I'm a 68-year-old man.
Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic keratosis.
